entry.title: What makes a site a blog?
entry.summary: Blogging is out, and the new trend is to tweet in Twitters. Syndication is out as well, since Google steals your content

div.p: Chris Anderson's new book has finally appeared. The new one, Free, much discussed already before it was printed, and, off course, much hyped in the Wired magazin.

How is this related to blogging? Well... I'd say: just about everything. Blog and wiki software were the first easy to really take advantage of the at the time new medium based on hypertext, a simple protocol and a global network. Blogs and wikis take advantage of this, and through additions such as syndication and pings (notifications that new content has appeared) and automatic cross-linking (based on pings) to enable discussions across blogs, it goes beyond hypertext. It creates a new medium which uses HTTP transaction to create human interaction.

When a blog really takes off, the traffic generated is enough for letting the ads pay your rent and buy milk for your kids. Obviously some quality is required or it won't take off in the first place. That is what gives the attention needed for the transactions to take place.

Blogging is cheap. You write about what's around you and what you know about. You benefit from from the transaction and attention economy which feeds the Internet. Syndication, aggregation, mashups and harvesting will move you're content around, and you'll actually mostly benefit from it. On the other hand, much of the user's navigation will take place elsewhere, and many user's will not be exposed to your ads but Google's. This lead to Jakob Nielsen's out-cry where he labelled them as leeches already a few years ago.
Michael Massing discusses this and other issues in a recent article in The New York Review of Books. He quotes David Simon's statement in a testimony in front of the US Senate:
div.blockquote: [Internet] leeches...reporting from mainstream news publications, whereupon aggregating websites and bloggers contribute little more than repetition, commentary and froth. Meanwhile, readers acquire news from the aggregators and abandon its point of originâ€”namely the newspapers themselves. In short, the parasite is slowly killing the host.
div.p: There is a problem deep in this statement. It assumes that there would be no news unless the more traditional media is there. We can be almost certain that this is not the case. Massing continues:
div.blockquote: ... such statements seem as outdated as they are defensive. Over the past few months alone, a remarkable amount of original, exciting, and creative (if also chaotic and maddening) material has appeared on the Internet. The practice of journalism, far from being leeched by the Web, is being reinvented there, with a variety of fascinating experiments in the gathering, presentation, and delivery of news. And unless the editors and executives at our top papers begin to take note, they will hasten their own demise.
div.p: Do we really need these big media institutions? I'd say we could do without them. The notion that we cannot get proper information from distant places without having expensive foreign correspondents travelling there seems extremely arrogant to me. This is not to say that we don't need journalism. Indeed we do, but one which has adapted to the medium. One which is part of the transaction & interaction based technology and economy which is the basis for the new media.
